children.subject: In the past 3 weeks, there have been at least 12 students fill out the EE/EECS form requesting to override a CS time conflict. Please make sure you are using the correct form.

Per several posts, I am not answering Piazza questions here and ask that students email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu with EE and EECS course enrollment questions. I will answer this here, however, because I do believe this is a bug. I've seen this scenario with several students now in different EE classes. Please email sishelp@berkeley.edu to confirm that this is a bug. I see the same info that you do and have the same issue with a student's lab or discussion disappearing although they are enrolled.
Thank you! I'll email them right now :)

I was enrolled in EE16A. After I tried to swap into another discussion section, there was a message saying success and it has been updated. But checking on Calcentral , now I don't have a discussion section at all (even though I'm still enrolled in the class). Is this a bug? I try swapping discussion sections now and it says it's can't since I have no "FROM" class. Please help ?

Yes, that is your waitlist position for the class, which is how waitlist positions are processed.

Note that what a lot of people say is mostly correct but also not exactly.

Getting into a discussion section is part of getting into the class. If you are first on the waitlist for the course, but your section is full, it won't be able to enroll, even if there is open space elsewhere in the class. (Conversely, if your section has open space but you can't enroll in lecture, e.g. due to enrollment restrictions on the course or a time conflict, you equally can't enroll either.)

It is not that "once you get into the section, you get into the class", since you cannot get into the section without getting into the class (this is not a cause and effect, but a simultaneous occurrence).

Also, in addition to just taking into account the length of the waitlist, you should also look at the actual amount of open space in the section. Both are equally relevant.

The post says that “Wait lists are automatically processed in numerical order based on the waitlist position.”

My question is does this mean the numerical order shown on My Academics?

A lot of people have told me that I should switch into a discussion section with the shortest waitlist and once I get into that section, I get into the class. 

Any clarification is highly appreciated! Happy holidays!

If, when the waitlist is next processed after seat restrictions are removed, this is still the case, and you have nothing else blocking you from enrolling (like time conflicts), then yes.

But other students could still enroll, or already-enrolled students can change their section time.

Or the course / section could be canceled. Or the enrollment system breaks. Or other unlikely occurrences.

So no, nothing is guaranteed.

I’m waitlisted for 170. 
Currently I’m in a section with available space of 21 and waitlist total of 17. Since the number of people on the waitlist for this section is smaller than the number of available seats, does this mean I’m guaranteed to get into this class (once the reserved seats are open)?

Thank you so much!
If you also had a time conflict, you should complete the form again.

If I do not have a time conflict and my only issue was that it couldn’t enroll me due to the unit cap, will it continue to process my enrollment as usual? 

Also has this changed my waitlist position within my discussion section at all?

Assuming nothing else is blocking your enrollment, you should have been enrolled the next time the waitlist processes.

Your waitlist position within a discussion can only change if either students ahead of you drop or get enrolled (so you move up) or an enrolled student switches to your discussion and moves to the first position on the waitlist (so you move down).
CS 188 is a CS course; this post is about EE and EECS courses. Please see the pinned CS course enrollment posts.

I was sent an automated email informing that I have not been enrolled in CS188 because I exceeded the max unit cap. 

The system skipped me when enrolling students, so now that I have dropped my number of units, will it continue to try to enroll me or are there steps I need to take now that I have been “skipped over”?

There is no such thing as a "time conflict override removed". Someone can manually enroll in you in the course, but the enrollment system itself has no knowledge of this.

In this case, the class is full, so no one can manually enroll you.

Okay I see, but since I have a time conflict and I am on the wait list as well, is there no way I will get off the wait list because of the time conflict? Will the EECS conflict override form help me at all? Because it seems that I was supposed to get in which is why I received the notification saying that I was not enrolled from the wait list because I have a time conflict.

You can only get off the waitlist if someone manually processes the form when there is open space in the class.

The override form helps you, in the sense that without it, you absolutely can't get in. With it, you just have a low chance of getting in.

I am currently on the wait list for EECS126. I have a time conflict with another class and it looks like I will not be enrolled from the wait list unless a time conflict has been resolved. I submitted the Google form in December too but I got the same notification just now. Was my original request not processed or was the time conflict override removed? I have submitted the form again.

history.content:
The CS side did such a nice job of breaking down their enrollment procedures so I am copying them. I hope that this is useful if you are still on waitlists, especially for EE16A and EE16B as there are currently still open seats (12/18).

  1. To see who can enroll into EE lower div classes and when, read: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy#lower

     

  2. Waitlist Processing:

    -Wait lists are automatically processed in numerical order based on the waitlist position. A student’s major is NOT taken into consideration when the wait list is processed.

    -If a student has a time conflict between the class and another, the system will NOT enroll them – they will be skipped when the list is processed. Time conflicts require manual enrollment. (See the note about the EE/EECS Time Conflict Override form.)

    -If enrolling the student into the class will put them over the maximum number of units, the system will also skip the student when processing the wait list. Units for wait listed classes count towards the upper unit limit: 13.5 phase 1, 17.5 phase 2, and 20 units over all.

    -Students on the waitlist for a class are NOT guaranteed to get into the class and should make a reasonable back-up plan.

  3. EE16B DIS 218. 

    -This is a faux section that allows students to help students enroll in the course.

    -DIS 218 has no scheduled day or time which reduces the number of time conflicts that must be processed online. Once the semester begins, students will attend DIS 201-217 as long as there is physical space in the classroom.

    -Students can still see the actual section days/times via classes.berkeley.edu

  4. Changing secondary sections in EE16A and EE16B. 

    -Students must enroll in 3 components: lecture, lab section, and discussion section.

    -In order to successfully enroll into the lecture, students need to select both a discussion and lab section that has available seats. If students select a lab/discussion section that is full, they will automatically be waitlisted for the class.

    -Students who are enrolled in the class may use the swap feature to change sections.

    -Students who are waitlisted cannot use the swap feature and must drop/re-enroll to change sections.

    -WARNING: Dropping and re-enrolling into another section that does not have space will cause you to drop to the bottom of the waitlist! If that happens, we cannot reinstate you to your prior place on the waitlist, even if you selected a full section by mistake.

  5. Time Conflicts:

    In the event of a time conflict – students need to complete the EE/EECS Time Conflict Override form. This is a different form than the form indicated on Cal Central.

 

  • This form is to request to overrides into EE & EECS classes only.

  • It is the student’s responsibility to check the attendance policy of the conflicting classes and make plans for conflicting midterms/finals.

  • Processed every Mon/Wed/Fri. Here’s how EE & EECS time conflicts are processed:

    1. If there is space available in the class and the student will not go over the unit limit, the student is enrolled.

    2. If there is no space in the lecture or section the student has requested, or if the student will go over the unit limit with enrollment, the student is not enrolled.

          If you submit the EE/EECS Time Conflict Override form and are not enrolled by the next Mon/Wed/Fri, you need to re-submit the form to indicate you still want to get into the class!

          If you submit the EE/EECS Time Conflict Override form and are not enrolled by the next Mon/Wed/Fri, you need to re-submit the form to indicate you still want to get into the class!
